paper_id: Impact of potassium management on soil dynamics and crop uptake in rice systems

paper_metadata.title: Impact of potassium management on soil dynamics and crop uptake in rice systems
paper_metadata.research_focus: Evaluation of different potassium (K) management strategies on soil K dynamics, balance, and crop uptake in a puddled, transplanted rice–rice system.
paper_metadata.soil_k_relevance: The study is centrally focused on soil potassium, investigating the dynamics of exchangeable, non-exchangeable, and reserve K pools, their contribution to crop uptake, and the overall K balance under various management practices to ensure sustainable rice production.

research_context.study_objectives: To evaluate the effects of different K management strategies on soil K dynamics, crop uptake, and grain yield in a puddled, transplanted rice–rice cropping system. Specifically, to analyze the contributions of exchangeable, non-exchangeable, and reserve K to the overall nutrient supply, and to understand how integrated nutrient management approaches can contribute to a positive K balance while sustaining high crop yields.
research_context.soil_k_research_role: Soil potassium dynamics, pools (exchangeable, non-exchangeable, reserve K), and balance are the primary focus of the research, serving as key indicators for assessing the sustainability and effectiveness of various K management strategies.
research_context.geographic_setting: Central Research Station of Orissa University of Agriculture and Technology (OUAT), Bhubaneswar, India (20°15′N, 81°52′E; 25.5 m above sea level). Located in the Eastern and South-Eastern Coastal Plain agroclimatic zone.
research_context.environmental_conditions: Hot and humid climate. Mean annual rainfall of 1,467 mm (approximately 70% occurring between July and September). Mean maximum temperature of 33.2°C and minimum temperature of 21.4°C. Shallow water table (1 m), leading to poorly drained land during the rainy season but moderately well drained during the summer.
research_context.agricultural_context: Puddled, transplanted rice–rice cropping system. Intensive rice farming practices with high-yielding rice varieties.
research_context.study_design: Randomized block design (RBD) with three replications. Nine treatments (T1-T9) including combinations of chemical fertilizers, straw application, and foliar spray.
research_context.temporal_scope: Conducted during dry (December–April) and wet (June–October) seasons. Soil samples collected at the beginning of the experiment, mid-season (30 and 60 days after transplanting - DAT), and after harvest. Plant samples collected at maximum tillering (MT), panicle initiation (PI), and harvest stages.
research_context.spatial_scope: Experimental plots measured 6 m × 5 m. Soil samples collected from three depths: 0–15 cm, 15–30 cm, and 30–45 cm.

concentration_measurements.spatial_context: 0–15 cm, 15–30 cm, and 30–45 cm soil depths, respectively

concentration_measurements.measurement_method: Nitric acid extraction (Wood and De Turk, 1941)
HNO₃–HClO₄ digestion, analyzed using flame photometer
HNO₃–HClO₄ digestion, analyzed using flame photometer

pool_characterizations.measurement_conditions: Surface (0–15 cm) and Subsurface (15–30 cm) soil depths
pool_characterizations.temporal_variation: Measured at Maximum Tillering (MT), Panicle Initiation (PI), and Harvest

pool_characterizations.measurement_conditions: Surface (0–15 cm) and Subsurface (15–30 cm) soil depths
pool_characterizations.temporal_variation: Measured at Maximum Tillering (MT) and Harvest

pool_characterizations.measurement_conditions: Surface (0–15 cm) and Subsurface (15–30 cm) soil depths
pool_characterizations.temporal_variation: Measured at Maximum Tillering (MT) and Harvest

pool_characterizations.measurement_conditions: Surface (0–15 cm) and Subsurface (15–30 cm) soil depths
pool_characterizations.temporal_variation: Measured at Maximum Tillering (MT) and Harvest

pool_characterizations.measurement_conditions: Surface (0–15 cm) and Subsurface (15–30 cm) soil depths
pool_characterizations.temporal_variation: Measured at Maximum Tillering (MT) and Harvest

pool_characterizations.measurement_conditions: Surface (0–15 cm) and Subsurface (15–30 cm) soil depths
pool_characterizations.temporal_variation: Measured at Maximum Tillering (MT) and Harvest

balance_calculations.sample_context: T9 (40 kg K₂O ha⁻¹ + 1% KNO₃ spray)

temporal_patterns.study_duration: Two cropping seasons: Dry (December–April) and Wet (June–October), implying at least one full year of observation.
temporal_patterns.monitoring_frequency: Soil samples collected at the beginning of the experiment, mid-season (30 and 60 DAT), and after harvest. Plant samples collected at maximum tillering (MT), panicle initiation (PI), and harvest stages.

seasonal_observations.seasonal_pattern: Lower in the dry season (DS) compared to the wet season (WS) at all growth stages.
In DS, 59–64% of total K uptake occurred post-panicle initiation (PI). In WS, K uptake was more evenly distributed: 16–18% by MT, 38–44% between MT and PI, and 40–44% between PI and maturity.
Generally higher in the DS compared to the WS.
drivers: Greater K release from soil reserves during DS (soil drying, reduced leaching)

seasonal_observations.seasonal_pattern: Declined at harvest in DS (indicative of active release to meet crop demands). Higher NE-K levels recorded in WS at harvest.
drivers: Active soil K release under intensive cropping (DS)
Reduced crop uptake and enhanced K retention due to higher soil moisture (WS)

seasonal_observations.seasonal_pattern: Consistently higher in the DS compared to the WS. Declined from MT to PI in both seasons, followed by an increase at harvest.
drivers: Mobilization to meet crop needs during critical growth stages
Replenishment through root turnover and microbial activity
Enhanced mineral weathering and nutrient cycling under wet conditions (WS)

within_site_variability.variability_description: Consistently higher in the topsoil (0–15 cm) than in the subsoil (15–30 cm and 30–45 cm) across both seasons.
Varied significantly among treatments and depths.

cycling_processes.description: Greater K release from soil reserves observed during the dry season, possibly due to soil drying and reduced leaching.
cycling_processes.measurement_approach: Inferred from higher available K levels in DS

cycling_processes.process_name: Conversion of Non-exchangeable K to Exchangeable K
cycling_processes.description: Evident in the dry season, where NE-K levels declined at harvest, indicating active soil K release to meet crop demands.
cycling_processes.measurement_approach: Observed decline in NE-K levels at harvest

cycling_processes.description: Reserve K declined from maximum tillering (MT) to panicle initiation (PI) in both seasons, suggesting mobilization to meet crop needs during critical growth stages.
cycling_processes.measurement_approach: Observed decline in Reserve K levels

cycling_processes.description: Followed by an increase at harvest, suggesting replenishment through root turnover and microbial activity.
cycling_processes.measurement_approach: Observed increase in Reserve K levels at harvest

plant_soil_interactions.description: Potassium uptake by the crop was lower in the dry season (DS) than in the wet season (WS) at all growth stages. Maximum K uptake in DS occurred between PI and harvest, while in WS, uptake was higher between MT and PI.

plant_soil_interactions.interaction_type: Correlation between soil K forms and plant K uptake
plant_soil_interactions.description: Total K uptake was significantly correlated with available K at MT (R² = 0.63), PI (R² = 0.49), and harvest (R² = 0.50) stages. Reserve K at PI and harvest stages also significantly correlated with total K uptake (R² = 0.52). Non-exchangeable K significantly correlated with K uptake at MT (R² = 0.43).
plant_soil_interactions.temporal_patterns: Correlations observed at specific growth stages.

chemical_processes.characterization: Implied by the dynamics of exchangeable K, which is readily available in soil solution and on exchange sites, and its replenishment from other pools.
chemical_processes.implications: Influences immediate K availability for crop uptake.

chemical_processes.characterization: Implied by the dynamics of reserve K, which can be mobilized to meet crop needs and replenished.

soil_k_effects.grain_yield: Lowest (2.69 t ha⁻¹ DS, 4.21 t ha⁻¹ WS)
soil_k_effects.plant_k_uptake: Lowest (74 kg ha⁻¹ DS, 87 kg ha⁻¹ WS at harvest)
soil_k_effects.non_exchangeable_k: Varied, but generally lower or showed depletion
soil_k_effects.k_balance: Negative (-103 kg ha⁻¹ DS, -87 kg ha⁻¹ WS, -103 kg ha⁻¹ annual)

mechanisms: No K input, leading to K mining

soil_k_effects.grain_yield: Increased compared to control (3.2 t ha⁻¹ DS, 4.3 t ha⁻¹ WS)

mechanisms: Direct K input from chemical fertilizer

soil_k_effects.grain_yield: Significantly higher, at par with T9 (3.5 t ha⁻¹ DS, 4.7 t ha⁻¹ WS)
soil_k_effects.non_exchangeable_k: Highest surface NE-K at harvest DS (152.4 kg ha⁻¹)

mechanisms: Direct K input from chemical fertilizer

soil_k_effects.grain_yield: Significantly higher, at par with T9 (3.4 t ha⁻¹ DS, 4.9 t ha⁻¹ WS)
soil_k_effects.plant_k_uptake: Highest total K uptake (147 kg ha⁻¹ DS, 156 kg ha⁻¹ WS at harvest)
soil_k_effects.non_exchangeable_k: Highest subsurface NE-K at MT WS (140.5 kg ha⁻¹), highest surface NE-K at harvest WS (226.2 kg ha⁻¹)
soil_k_effects.reserve_k: Highest levels in DS and WS

mechanisms: Direct K input from chemical fertilizer

experimental_treatments.treatment_description: T5: 20 kg K₂O ha⁻¹ + straw (3 t ha⁻¹, ~45 kg K ha⁻¹)

soil_k_effects.grain_yield: Increased compared to control (3.2 t ha⁻¹ DS, 4.4 t ha⁻¹ WS)
soil_k_effects.non_exchangeable_k: Highest surface NE-K at MT DS (97.9 kg ha⁻¹), highest subsurface NE-K at MT DS (147.7 kg ha⁻¹), lowest surface NE-K at MT WS (78.8 kg ha⁻¹), highest subsurface NE-K at harvest WS (149.5 kg ha⁻¹)
soil_k_effects.k_balance: Positive (53 kg ha⁻¹ DS, 53 kg ha⁻¹ annual)

mechanisms: Combined inorganic and organic K input
slow release of K from straw

soil_k_effects.grain_yield: Significantly higher, at par with T9 (3.5 t ha⁻¹ DS, 5.2 t ha⁻¹ WS)
soil_k_effects.exchangeable_k: Highest surface exchangeable K at MT WS (81.7 kg ha⁻¹)
soil_k_effects.reserve_k: Maintained adequate levels, highest subsurface reserve K at harvest WS (203 kg ha⁻¹)
soil_k_effects.k_balance: Positive (65 kg ha⁻¹ WS, 65 kg ha⁻¹ annual)

mechanisms: Combined inorganic and organic K input
slow release of K from straw

soil_k_effects.grain_yield: Significantly higher, at par with T9 (3.1 t ha⁻¹ DS, 4.9 t ha⁻¹ WS)
soil_k_effects.exchangeable_k: Highest subsurface exchangeable K at MT WS (55.3 kg ha⁻¹)

mechanisms: Combined inorganic and organic K input
slow release of K from straw

experimental_treatments.treatment_description: T8: Straw alone (3 t ha⁻¹, ~45 kg K ha⁻¹)

soil_k_effects.grain_yield: Increased compared to control (2.8 t ha⁻¹ DS, 4.6 t ha⁻¹ WS)
soil_k_effects.plant_k_uptake: Lowest K uptake at MT (16.1 kg ha⁻¹ DS, 21.9 kg ha⁻¹ WS)
soil_k_effects.non_exchangeable_k: Lowest surface NE-K at MT DS (35.5 kg ha⁻¹), lowest subsurface NE-K at MT DS (74.5 kg ha⁻¹), lowest subsurface NE-K at harvest WS (130.6 kg ha⁻¹)

mechanisms: slow release of K from straw

experimental_treatments.treatment_description: T9: 40 kg K₂O ha⁻¹ + 1% KNO₃ foliar spray at panicle initiation stage

soil_k_effects.grain_yield: Highest (3.84 t ha⁻¹ DS, 5.35 t ha⁻¹ WS)
soil_k_effects.plant_k_uptake: Highest K uptake at MT DS (19.1 kg ha⁻¹)
soil_k_effects.non_exchangeable_k: Lowest surface NE-K at harvest DS (83.3 kg ha⁻¹)

mechanisms: Direct K input from chemical fertilizer and rapid K availability from foliar spray, leading to high K removal by crop

management_practices.soil_k_impacts: Maintained higher exchangeable and reserve K levels. Generally led to negative K balances due to high crop removal.
management_practices.implementation_details: Applied in two equal splits at basal application and 50 DAT.

management_practices.soil_k_impacts: Contributed ~45 kg K ha⁻¹. Enhanced soil organic matter. Contributed to slow release of K. Led to positive K balances when combined with reduced fertilizer doses or alone.
management_practices.implementation_details: Panicles removed, 5 cm straw left, field dried, straw mixed with power tiller to shallow depth, second plowing after 15 days.
management_practices.temporal_effects: Slow release of K over time, long-term soil health benefits.

management_practices.soil_k_impacts: Enhanced nutrient use efficiency and crop productivity. Led to the most negative K balance due to high crop uptake.
management_practices.implementation_details: Applied at the panicle initiation stage.
management_practices.temporal_effects: Rapid K availability during critical growth stage.
management_practices.spatial_effects: Directly on plant foliage, indirect soil K impact through high removal.

comparative_analysis.comparison_type: Fertilizer K vs. Fertilizer K + Straw

soil_k_differences.k_balance: Fertilizer K alone showed negative K balances, while combined treatments showed positive K balances.
soil_k_differences.non_exchangeable_k_utilization: Reduced fertilizer doses combined with straw utilized more non-exchangeable K.

soil_k_differences.exchangeable_k: Generally higher in DS than WS.
soil_k_differences.reserve_k: Consistently higher in DS than WS.
soil_k_differences.non_exchangeable_k_shift: DS exhibited a greater shift in non-exchangeable K, indicative of larger soil K depletion.
soil_k_differences.k_uptake_partitioning: Greater reliance on post-PI K uptake in DS (59-64%) vs. more even distribution in WS (38-44% MT-PI, 40-44% PI-maturity).

analytical_methods.instrumentation: Not specified for extraction, but plant K analyzed by flame photometer.
Not specified for extraction, but plant K analyzed by flame photometer.
Not specified for extraction, but plant K analyzed by flame photometer.

analytical_methods.procedure_description: Digestion using HNO₃–HClO₄ (3:2), diluted with distilled water.

sampling_design.spatial_sampling: Soil samples collected from three depths (0–15, 15–30, and 30–45 cm). Experimental plots measured 6 m × 5 m.
sampling_design.temporal_sampling: Soil samples collected at the beginning of the experiment, mid-season (30 and 60 DAT), and after harvest. Plant samples collected at maximum tillering, panicle initiation, and harvest stages.
sampling_design.sample_processing: Soil samples: air-dried, crushed, and sieved through a 2-mm mesh. Plant samples: dried (70 ± 5°C), weighed, and ground using a Willey mill.
sampling_design.representativeness: Three replications for each treatment in a randomized block design.

climate_conditions.precipitation: Mean annual rainfall 1,467 mm, approximately 70% occurring between July and September.
climate_conditions.seasonality: Hot and humid climate with distinct dry (December–April) and wet (June–October) seasons.

chemical_properties.exchangeable_k: Low (1 N NH₄OAc-K: 58 kg ha⁻¹ at 0-15 cm)

physical_properties.drainage: Poorly drained during rainy season, moderately well drained during summer due to shallow water table.

landscape_context.drainage: Poorly drained during rainy season, moderately well drained during summer due to shallow water table.
landscape_context.position: Central Research Station of Orissa University of Agriculture and Technology (OUAT), Bhubaneswar, India. Eastern and South-Eastern Coastal Plain agroclimatic zone.
landscape_context.land_use_history: Puddled, transplanted rice–rice cropping system, intensive rice farming.

research_integration.relationship_to_other_measurements: Soil K dynamics (exchangeable, non-exchangeable, reserve K) are directly linked to grain yield and plant K uptake. K balance calculations integrate K inputs (fertilizer, straw) and outputs (crop removal).
research_integration.integration_with_plant_studies: Plant K uptake was measured at different growth stages (MT, PI, harvest) and correlated with soil K forms. Grain yield was a key outcome measure influenced by K management.
research_integration.connection_to_broader_objectives: The findings inform sustainable nutrient management strategies for rice-based cropping systems, aiming to optimize soil K dynamics, enhance soil fertility, reduce dependence on external inputs, and ensure long-term food security and agricultural viability.
research_integration.comparative_context: Compares different K management strategies (chemical fertilizers, straw incorporation, foliar spray) and their effects across dry and wet seasons.
research_integration.literature_positioning: Corroborates previous studies on integrated nutrient management, K depletion, and the role of non-exchangeable K, while providing season-specific insights for rice systems in India.

temporal_limitations: The study is not long-term; cumulative effects of different K management strategies on soil health and sustainability require further long-term studies.
spatial_limitations: Conducted at a single site, limiting generalizability to other agroecological contexts without further validation.
methodological_constraints: Further research is needed to explore the potential of other organic amendments (e.g., green manures, composts) beyond straw.
Interactions between K and other nutrients (N, P) merit further study for optimized nutrient management.
interpretation_caveats: Socioeconomic studies are needed to evaluate the feasibility and adoption of integrated nutrient management practices among smallholder farmers.

extraction_assessment.extraction_notes: All explicit quantitative soil K measurements, pool characterizations, and balance calculations were extracted. Ranges and specific values for different treatments, depths, and time points were included where available. The paper did not provide specific values for non-exchangeable and reserve K at 15-30 and 30-45 cm depths initially, only stating 'corresponding increases'. Process rates were inferred from K balance and uptake data rather than direct rate measurements. Figures were described qualitatively as quantitative data was presented in text or tables. Table 2 data was fully incorporated into K balance calculations.

_usage_metadata.paper_id: Impact of potassium management on soil dynamics and crop uptake in rice systems
